summary: Email chain between Assistant U.S. Attorney and defense attorney Laura Menninger regarding discovery issues in US v. Maxwell, focusing on discrepancies in the count of 'Highly Confidential' images/videos, logistical problems with evidence review, and defense requests for access to materials. The chain reveals confusion over the number of nude/semi-nude images (initially thought to be ~5,500, but an FBI 302 report indicates ~33,747 images and 895 videos) and ongoing disputes over evidence production formats and access.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell; corresponds with prosecutors about discovery deficiencies, including discrepancies in image counts and access to 'Highly Confidential' materials.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Contractor for the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York; copied on emails regarding discovery issues in US v. Maxwell.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney copied on email correspondence regarding discovery deficiencies in US v. Maxwell.

connections.description: Correspondence regarding discovery issues, with Menninger as defense attorney and Pagliuca as a contractor for the prosecution, discussing evidence counts and access.
Both are defense attorneys involved in the Maxwell case, copied on emails about discovery problems.

events.title: Defense Review of HC Materials in New York
events.description: Defense counsel reviewed 'Highly Confidential' images on hard drives at 500 Pearl Street, initially told there were approximately 5,500 images, but later discovery indicates a much larger number.

events.title: Production of Confidential Images
events.description: The government produced confidential images in html files, referenced in email correspondence about evidence formats.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date for US v. Maxwell
events.description: Trial date set for November 29, 2021, mentioned in context of discovery deadlines and evidence review timelines.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (location where defense reviewed evidence)
Denver, CO (location of defense counsel's office and FBI field office for evidence review)
New York, NY (Southern District of New York U.S. Attorney's Office)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Ghislaine Maxwell was held)
keyFacts: Significant discrepancy in 'Highly Confidential' image counts: initially ~5,500 images were made available for review, but an FBI 302 report indicated ~33,747 images and 895 videos from CART-processed evidence.
Over 40,000 non-nude images and over 3,400 nude images were extracted from CDs seized from Epstein's New York residence.
Defense reported widespread problems with evidence review, including corrupt files, unreadable photo formats, and missing metadata, hindering their ability to prepare for trial.

The government maintained strict controls over 'Highly Confidential' materials (nude/sexualized images), requiring review on government laptops under FBI supervision, rather than providing copies to defense.
Email chain reveals ongoing disputes and miscommunications between prosecution and defense regarding evidence production, with defense threatening to seek court intervention.
